clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of PEP on IC During IT in Patients With COPD
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Positive Expiratory Pressure on Inspiratory Capacity and Dyspnea in Patients With COPD During Exercise

lead_sponsor.agency: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

clinical_study.source: Cliniques universitaires Saint-Luc- Université Catholique de Louvain

brief_summary.textblock: This study will investigate the effects of positive expiratory pressure (PEP) on hyperinflation in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the primary outcome

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a cross-over intervention assessing the effect of PEP on IC and dyspnea in patients with COPD performing an interval training (IT) session.
IC will be measured before, during and immediately after the IT session. Each participant will receive perform IT sessions including either the use of a PEP of 10 cmH2O or a PEP of 1 cmH2O. The effects on IC and dyspnea on both PEP levels will be assessed.

primary_outcome.description: Evolution of inspiratory capacity while performing the interval training session

secondary_outcome.description: Evolution of dyspnea while performing the interval training session

arm_group.description: In this arm, patients will receive the experimental condition first, then the sham condition
In this arm, patients will receive the sham condition first, then the experimental condition

intervention.description: Bottle PEP with a water level of 10 cmH2O
Bottle PEP with a water level of 1 cmH2O

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Stable COPD since 1 month at least
- Able to understand the instructions
Exclusion Criteria:
- COPD with a forced expiratory volume at one second > 80% of predicted values
- In exacerbation
- Orthopedic of neurological condition likely to interfere with the experimentation
- Contraindication to perform exercise
